text: in aleppo's war there's nowhere to hide
this family was bombed even as they fled
the images are too gruesome to show in
detail all they had was each other now
not even that as my mum was picking up a
suitcase the first of the bombs hit
we're on my mom was lying here dead
my sister was lying there the other one
right beside her was still alive we
don't know anything about my sister yet
she's at hospital and then the second
bomb hit just here still the battle goes
on the Syrian military backed by Iranian
and Russian allies continues its advance
deep into the rebel-held enclaves
fighting an array of groups some backed
by the West some linked to al-qaeda
trapped in the middle tens of thousands
of civilians on the run not sure where
to turn some speak of threats from
rebels - this woman tells Iranian
television she came under sniper fire
we ran fast she says yes he was sniping
at us far from this battleground at the
United Nations in New York a war of
words over the desperate plight of the
people of Aleppo history may show that
it is perhaps the most horrific conflict
of our lifetimes if the West are really
worried about the situation they should
take practical steps and stop supporting
terrorists more strong language there's
already been so much and so little
impact on the ground there is some help
for those who fled shelters in the
government-controlled area of West
Aleppo but many are already full this
camp is run by the International
Committee of the Red Cross
their spokesman in Damascus told me as
bad as it is he fears it will get worse
the people will be on the move the
people will have to flee their houses we
don't know yet where we don't know how
our biggest fear is to guarantee their
safety precious moments when life is so
precarious how they matter when the
future for them their city remains so
uncertain please do set BBC News
Damascus
